section.section:
The Secretary may only designate an area as an enterprise zone if the area:
is in a priority funding area or meets an exception under Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
satisfies at least one of the requirements specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

In determining if an area meets the requirements of this subsection, the Secretary may consider the most recent census data provided by the United States Bureau of the Census or any other reliable data that is acceptable to the Secretary.

Before considering data other than the most recent census in making a determination under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection, the Secretary shall adopt regulations specifying alternative data that are satisfactory to the Secretary.
The Secretary may establish by regulation any other requirements necessary and appropriate to carry out this subtitle.
Before designating an enterprise zone, the Secretary shall consult with the appropriate advisors.
Within 60 days after a submission date, the Secretary may designate one or more enterprise zones from among the areas described in the applications timely submitted.
The designation of an area as an enterprise zone is effective for 10 years.
The Secretary may not designate more than six enterprise zones in a calendar year.
A county may not receive more than two enterprise zones in a calendar year.

text.section: The designation of the Secretary is final.
At any time, a political subdivision may reapply to the Secretary to designate as an enterprise zone an area that is not designated.
